message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The inherited deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A is known as Fabry disease, which leads to the accumulation of ceramide trihexose in the tissue. Angiokeratomas, small red-purple skin lesions, are a common finding in Fabry disease. Cherry red spots on macula are seen in Tay-Sachs disease, histiocytes with a wrinkled tissue paper appearance are seen in Gaucher disease, and corneal clouding is seen in Hurler syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The inherited deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A results in Fabry disease, which causes the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide (ceramide trihexose) in tissues. Angiokeratomas are a common dermatologic manifestation of Fabry disease. Cherry red spots on the macula are seen in Tay-Sachs disease, histiocytes with a wrinkled tissue paper appearance are seen in Gaucher's disease, and corneal clouding is seen in Hurler's syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description matches Fabry disease, which is caused by a deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A. The accumulation of ceramide trihexose in the tissues leads to angiokeratomas, which are red or purple lesions on the skin. Cherry red spots on macula are associated with Tay-Sachs disease, and histiocytes with a wrinkled tissue paper appearance are seen in Gaucher disease. Corneal clouding is seen in several lysosomal storage disorders, including mucopolysaccharidoses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of an inherited deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A and accumulation of ceramide trihexose in the tissue is suggestive of Fabry disease. Angiokeratomas, which are small red or blue papules, are a common finding in Fabry disease. Cherry red spots on macula are seen in Tay-Sachs disease, histiocytes with a wrinkled tissue paper appearance are seen in Gaucher disease, and corneal clouding is seen in various mucopolysaccharidoses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An inherited deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A is characteristic of Fabry disease, which causes the accumulation of glycosphingolipids, specifically ceramide trihexose. One of the clinical manifestations of Fabry disease is angiokeratomas, which are dark red or blue-black warty papules that usually occur in the pubic region and lower trunk. The other options are characteristic of other lysosomal storage disorders.

Angiokeratomas are a well-known cutaneous manifestation of Fabry disease. The other options are associated with different lysosomal storage disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A leads to Fabry disease, which causes angiokeratomas. Cherry red spots on macula are seen in Tay-Sachs disease. Histiocytes with a wrinkled tissue paper appearance are seen in Gaucher disease. Corneal clouding is seen in Hurler syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Alpha-galactosidase A deficiency causes Fabry disease, which is associated with the accumulation of ceramide trihexose. Angiokeratomas are a common skin manifestation of Fabry disease. Cherry red spots on macula and histiocytes with wrinkled appearance are seen in Tay-Sachs disease and Gaucher disease, respectively. Corneal clouding is seen in mucopolysaccharidoses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The alpha-galactosidase A deficiency is a characteristic feature of Fabry disease, which results in the accumulation of ceramide trihexose in the tissue. This accumulation leads to the development of angiokeratomas, which are small, dark red or blue lesions on the skin. Cherry red spots on macula and histiocytes with a wrinkled tissue paper appearance are associated with Tay-Sachs disease and Gaucher disease, respectively. Corneal clouding is a feature of Hurler syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A results in Fabry disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide (GL-3) in various tissues. This accumulation leads to angiokeratomas, which are small, dark red, raised spots on the skin. Cherry red spots on macula are characteristic of Tay-Sachs disease, histiocytes with a wrinkled tissue paper appearance are seen in Gaucher disease, and corneal clouding is seen in mucopolysaccharidoses.
